title: Tampa
text:
The map displays the percentage of residents with doctorate degrees across different neighborhoods in Tampa and surrounding areas. The legend indicates percentages ranging from 0-6%, with purple representing the lowest rates (0-1%) and yellow representing the highest rates (around 6%).
Most of the mapped area shows deep purple coloring, indicating that the vast majority of neighborhoods have very low percentages of residents with doctorate degrees (0-1%). There are a few notable exceptions where small pockets show higher concentrations: A few scattered areas display green coloring (around 3-4%), particularly in the central part of Tampa and near the airport area. There are also one or two very small yellow spots showing the highest concentration of doctorate holders (5-6%).

title: Florida Education
text:
Florida Educational Attainment Analysis
This map shows the percentage of people in Florida with bachelor’s degrees or higher in different parts of the state. Coastal areas generally show darker purple coloring, indicating lower rates of bachelor’s degree attainment (0-20%). This pattern is particularly evident along both the eastern and western coastlines. Central inland areas display lighter coloring, suggesting higher educational attainment rates (30-50%). You can see that major urban areas visible on the map (like around Tampa, St. Petersburg, and Fort Lauderdale) show a combination of education levels in some neighborhoods while adjacent neighborhoods have rather low attainment levels.

title: About
text:
My name is Tyaveon Levit. I am A third Year Transfer, it is my first year here at new college New College Of Florida. I collected data of Bachelor Degree’s by percent from Florida counties as a whole and then continued to take a closer look at the Hillsborough county in particular and then into Tampa specifically being that is home for me. The repo for this project can be found here Email Me: t.levit28@ncf.edu
Here you can find the Techne Course homepage
Some basic information include, early education focusing on skills like writing, mathematics, and philosophy, often being reserved for elites.
To earn a Bachelor’s degree, students typically complete 12 years of primary and secondary education, followed by 3-4 years of undergraduate study at a college or university. This involves choosing a major, completing general education requirements, and earning a set number of credits through coursework, exams, and projects. Many programs also include internships or research opportunities. A Bachelor’s degree equips graduates with specialized knowledge, critical thinking skills, and better career prospects, serving as a foundation for advanced studies or professional success.
The data for this project came from the America Community survey.

title: About
text:
Purpose and Scope
The ACS aims to help communities, policymakers, and businesses make informed decisions by providing up-to-date statistics on topics such as: - Demographic characteristics (age, race, gender, education) - Economic indicators (income, employment, poverty) - Housing trends (homeownership, rent, housing costs) - Social factors (marital status, disability, transportation)

title: About
text:
Methodology
The survey reaches approximately 3.5 million households each year, sampling a small percentage of the population. Data is collected through online forms, mail, phone calls, and in-person interviews. The ACS produces 1-year, 3-year, and 5-year estimates, with the 5-year estimates offering the most comprehensive data for smaller geographic areas.

title: About
text:
Impact
The ACS is a critical tool for allocating federal funds, planning community services, and addressing social and economic challenges. Its data is widely used by governments, researchers, and businesses to understand trends and disparities across the United States.
For more information, visit the U.S. Census Bureau’s ACS website.

title: Hillsborough
text:
This map overlays doctorate degree attainment data on the greater Tampa Bay region, with specific focus on Hillsborough County. The visualization uses a color gradient from purple (0-1% doctorate holders) to yellow (6% doctorate holders), providing insight into the educational landscape of the area. Hillsborough County shows several notable patterns in its doctorate degree distribution:
The majority of the county displays deep purple coloring, indicating that most neighborhoods have relatively low percentages (0-1%) of residents with doctorate degrees. This pattern is consistent across much of the suburban and rural areas of the county. However, there are several notable clusters where higher concentrations of doctorate degree holders reside:
In the north Tampa area, particularly around the University of South Florida region, there are pockets of green and blue coloring, suggesting areas with 3-4% doctorate degree holders. This higher concentration likely reflects the presence of university faculty, researchers, and professionals associated with the academic institution.
The south Tampa peninsula shows some variation, with a mix of purple and blue areas, indicating slightly higher concentrations of doctorate holders in certain neighborhoods, particularly in some of the more affluent areas. The eastern portions of Hillsborough County, extending toward Plant City and the rural areas, consistently show lower percentages, predominantly in the 0-1% range. This reflects the more rural, agricultural nature of these areas.

title: Indian Creek
text:
This map shows Indian Creek area of Miami on the East coast of Florida. This area has a lot more blue and yellow indicating that these areas have 3.0% and higher of people who have attained a bachelors degree or more advanced levels of education.
The map focuses on a coastal area near Surfside, with major surrounding areas including Sunny Isles Beach to the north and Bal Harbour Village to the south. Florida State Road A1A is visible running through the region.
